page.title: 03 Local History
page.content: Seasalter was once a centre of the ancient salt making industry.Relics of the Roman, Saxon and Norse origin have been found in this area. Whitstable is renowned for its oysters which were first exported in Roman Times. Before the Norman Conquest the Great Forest of Blean stretched to the edge of the higher ground of the present town of Whitstable, and was called "Northwoods".From this name the Manor of Northwood, a forerunner of Whitstable took it's name.The Manor of Northwood may have been the Manor of Dodeham.The name Whitstable came from a staple, a pillar, and the white salt but some people think that the "Whit" part comes from "Witan" council wise men. During the Middle Ages local people were involed in agriculture and seafaring.
